Award.AwardTitle: Pan-American Advanced Studies Institute on Manufacturing Innovation through Sustainable Design; Barranquilla, Colombia, July 2013
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Pan-American Advanced Studies Institutes (PASI) award, jointly supported by the NSF and the Department of Energy (DOE), will take place July 14-27, 2013 at the Universidad del Norte in Barranquilla, Colombia. Organized by Dr. Ratna Babu Chinnam, Professor of the Industrial & Systems Engineering Department at Wayne State University, the institute will focus on novel approaches in sustainable manufacturing and design. The PASI will address the need for fundamental research and holistic training on many different topics related to sustainability, including materials, product design, production processes, supply chain management, and tools for sustainable innovation. The discussion will be integrated in a multidisciplinary fashion to nurture exploration of future directions for new research collaborations and industrial applications.

The institute is expected to enhance the infrastructure for research and education on the PASI topics through collaborations developed before, during, and beyond the activity, and by sharing resources. Additionally, it will facilitate future relationships between international participants, while promoting student exchanges in the Americas and an increase in the number of visiting scholars from other countries at participating universities. The nature of the PASI will also facilitate the participation of underrepresented groups in engineering. Results from the PASI will be disseminated through an institute website and journal publications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Pan-American Advanced Studies Institute (PASI) on Manufacturing Innovation through Sustainable Design was held at Universidad del Norte, Barranquilla, Colombia, July 14-27, 2013. It was organized by Wayne State University, Pennsylvania State University, Oregon State University, Universidad del Norte, Escuela Superior Politécnica del Litoral (ESPOL), Ecuador, and Universidad Tecnológica de Panamá. The institute hosted thirty early career researchers (M.S./Ph.D. students, post-docs, and assistant professors), with half from the U.S. and half from Mexico, Central America, and South America. About one-third of the participants were female. The institute provided lectures, industry tours, and a team-based proposal writing exercise. Each team presented their proposal idea to the full group, and received feedback for the development of the idea. Each team produced a proposal draft, which was reviewed by the organizers and lecturers, who provided feedback to the team. One of the Ph.D. student participants, who has since graduated, noted that this experience was highly valuable in her professional development for her current position as a post-doc pursuing a university research faculty career.

The institute was found to be very successful, with an average overall satisfaction of 92.6% based on a survey of participants.  Pre- and post-survey results showed that knowledge of key concepts increased over the course of the workshop.  A recent request for information from PASI participants showed that young faculty were awarded related funding from Chile, Virginia, and NSF, which they attributed to participation in the PASI. One project was derived from relationships forged at the PASI.  Several participants attributed recent publications to their experiences. At the Universidad del Norte, M.S. and Ph.D. research topics in electrical engineering are now being pursued in sustainability, and they have introduced concepts presented at the PASI to industry partners, who have adopted them as a part of their training. It is important to note that relationships established at the workshop led to ongoing collaborations for research and educational exchanges between the organizers, lecturers, and early career participants that have borne fruit and others that are still being cultivated. It is expected that the impacts of the workshop will continue to be felt through the education and training of students and mentees that interact by the many workshop participants as they advance through their careers in academia and industry.
